{{also|konnen|Können}} ==German== ===Etymology=== {{PIE root|de|ǵneh₃}} From {{inh|de|goh|kunnan}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*kunnaną}}, from {{der|de|ine-pro|*ǵneh₃-||to know}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈkœnən/|[ˈkœnən]|[ˈkœnn̩]}} * {{audio|de|De-können.ogg|audio}} ===Verb=== {{de-verb-irregular|kann|konnte|können|past participle 2=gekonnt|past subjunctive=könnte}} # {{lb|de|auxiliary|with an infinitive|past participle: “[[können]]”}} To [[be able to|be able]] (to do something); [[can]]. #: '''''Kannst''' du ihm helfen?'' — “Are you able to help him?” #: ''Ich hätte das machen '''können'''.'' — “I could have done that.” # {{lb|de|auxiliary|with an infinitive|past participle: “[[können]]”}} To be [[allowed]] (to do something); to be [[permitted]] (to do something); [[may]]. #: '''''Kann''' ich mitkommen?'' — “May I come along?” #: ''Er hat nicht ins Kino gehen '''können'''.'' — “He was not allowed to go to the cinema.” # {{lb|de|transitive|past participle: “[[gekonnt]]”}} To [[know]] how to do (something); to know; to [[understand]]; to be able to do (something); to be [[capable]] of; can do (something). #: ''Ich '''kann''' Deutsch und Englisch.'' — “I know German and English.” #: '''''Kannst''' du es?'' — “Can you do it?” #: ''Das hätte ich nicht '''gekonnt'''.'' — “I couldn’t have done that.” or “I wouldn’t have been capable of that.” # {{lb|de|intransitive|past participle: “[[gekonnt]]”}} To [[be able to]] do something implied; [[can]]. #: ''Nein, ich '''kann''' nicht.'' — “No, I can’t.” #: ''Er hat '''gekonnt'''.'' — “He was able to [do it].” # {{lb|de|intransitive|colloquial|usually in negation}} to be [[possible]], to [[make sense]] #: ''Nächstes Jahr is’n Schaltjahr.'' – ''Das '''kann''' nich’. Letztes Jahr war doch Schaltjahr!'' #:: Next year is a leap year. – That'''’s''' not '''possible'''. Last year was a leap year! ====Usage notes==== * As with all modal verbs, the auxiliary ''können'' is used with a following bare infinitive (see examples above). * In the perfect tense, when ''können'' is used as an auxiliary verb, the past participle must be ''können'' (or more accurately speaking: the infinitive is used instead of the past participle). When used as a main verb, the past participle ''gekonnt'' is standard usage. However, especially among southern speakers, the infinitive may also occur (''Er hat nicht können''. Instead of more correct: ''Er hat nicht gekonnt''.) * Unlike English, the use of {{m|de||können|t=can}} for {{m|de|dürfen|t=may}} is rarely ever frowned upon. In fact, {{m|de||können}} is preferable in some contexts. For example, when offering an empty seat next to one on a train, one would rather say: {{m|de||Sie können sich hier hinsetzen|t=You may come sit here}}, because {{m|de||dürfen}} might sound condescending (as though one had a right to forbid it). ====Conjugation==== {{de-conj-pp|könn|kann|konn|könn|gekonnt|h}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|Können}} * {{l|de|Könner}} * {{l|de|abkönnen}} * {{l|de|ankönnen}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} [[Category:German modal verbs]]
